tn.ref: it is severe for men
tn.text: AT: "it causes hardship for people"

tn.ref: riches, wealth
tn.text: These two words mean basically the same thing. They refer to money and the things that a person can buy with money. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: he lacks nothing
tn.text: AT: "he has everything"

tn.ref: God gives him no ability to enjoy it.
tn.text: To acquire riches or possessions and not be able to enjoy them is futile.

tn.ref: This is vapor, an evil affliction.
tn.text: To be unable to enjoy one's possessions is an evil affliction or curse.

tn.ref: fathers a hundred children
tn.text: AT: "fathers 100 children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: lives many years, so that the days of his years are many
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: his heart is not satisfied with good
tn.text: AT: "he is not content with good things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: he is not buried with honor
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "no one buries him" or 2) "no one buries him properly." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: such a baby is born in futility
tn.text: AT: "such a baby is born for nothing"

tn.ref: passes away in darkness
tn.text: Here the word "darkness" may refer either to the world of the dead or to something that is difficult to understand. AT: "dies unexplainably" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: its name remains hidden
tn.text: AT: "no one knows its name" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: it has rest even though that man did not
tn.text: A still born child never experienced hardship, it remained at rest. Whereas the man who lived many years without satisfaction lacks rest.

tn.ref: Even if a man should live for two thousand years
tn.text: This is an exaggeration to show that it does not matter how long a person lives if he does not enjoy the good things in life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: two thousand years
tn.text: AT: "2,000 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: but does not learn to enjoy good things
tn.text: This is the point, that man needs to learn to enjoy the good things life offers him.

tn.ref: to fill his mouth
tn.text: AT: "to put food in his mouth" or "to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: his appetite is not filled
tn.text: AT: "he does not satisfy his appetite" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: what advantage has the wise person over the fool?
tn.text: A wise person's wisdom does not entitle him to any additional comforts. AT: "the wise person has no advantage over the fool." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: What advantage does the poor man have even if he knows how to act in front of other people?
tn.text: AT: "The poor man has no advantage even if he knows how to act in front of other people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: what the eyes see
tn.text: A person can see these things because he already has them. AT: "what a person has" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to desire what a wandering appetite craves
tn.text: This refers to things that a person wants but does not have. AT: "to want what he does not have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: vapor and an attempt to shepherd the wind
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ecc:01:12|1:14]].

tn.ref: Whatever has existed has already been given its name
tn.text: AT: "People have already named everything that exists" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: what mankind is like has already been known
tn.text: AT: people already know what mankind is like" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The more words that are spoken
tn.text: AT: "The more words that people speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the more futility increases
tn.text: when there is much talk, the chances for idle, non-encouraging words to be spoken is greater than if only a few words are spoken. AT: "the more meaningless those words are"

tn.ref: what advantage is that to a man?
tn.text: There is no advantage for a man to talk a lot. AT: "that is no advantage to a man." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: For who knows what is good for man ... he passes like a shadow?
tn.text: AT: "No one knows what is good for man ... he passes like a shadow." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: numbered days through which he passes like a shadow
tn.text: Life is compared to a shadow that passes quickly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Who can tell a man what will come under the sun after he passes?
tn.text: AT: "No one can tell a man what will come under the sun after he passes." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: what will come under the sun
tn.text: This is another way of expressing what will happen in the future. AT: "what will happen on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: after he passes
tn.text: This is a polite expression for death. AT: "after he dies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
